instruction: [INST] Analyze this file to learn MacBook motherboard repair. The 'definitions' section explains key technical terms. The 'threads' section contains real-world repair discussions. Use both sections to understand and learn how to troubleshoot MacBook issues. Posts from username 'larossmann' , 'dukefawks' , and '2informaticos' are posts from trusted experts.[/INST]

definitions.820-01814: What is 820-01814? a LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER.
definitions.PPVOUT_S0_LCDBKLT: What is PPVOUT_S0_LCDBKLT? PPVOUT_S0_LCDBKLT is a power rail that powers the LED light in the screen of the device that allows you to see what is on the screen. When this is low or missing, the screen will be dim..

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-01814</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-A  No back light
threads.message:
Machine came in for no display.   Quickly figured out it was no back light.
no evidence of water damage.   Everything looks clean.


The back light enable is present,  Back light voltage at the caps of the buck converters is 55V (<SIGNAL>PPVOUT_SO_LCDBKLT</SIGNAL>)
but there is no back light.   Measured <SIGNAL>PPVOUT_S0_LCDBKLT</SIGNAL> on the plug to the LEDs on the display its self.

Tested with a tester display.   Nothing.

What am I missing here?  How do these work?

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-01814</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-A  No back light
threads.message:
High voltage means no contact with LEDs strip inside LCD assembly.
LCD connector, video cables, or LEDs strip as suspects.
Did you test with known good assembly?

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-01814</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-A  No back light
threads.message:
Yes I have tried two assemblies.   I have also measured voltage on the display directly.  55v on both

The 55v measurement on the display was with the backlight unplugged.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-01814</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-A  No back light
threads.message: Do you get 55V without LCD connected???

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-01814</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-A  No back light
threads.message: No.   I use a LCD board to test with.. so it enables the back light so I can check it's output.   Makes it easy when the LB is just on the bench.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-01814</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-A  No back light
threads.message: "LCD connector, video cables, or LEDs strip as suspects."

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-01814</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-A  No back light
threads.message:
LCD connector has been replaced.   Tried two known good test screens.  :(
ohm'ed out the <SIGNAL>PPVOUT_SO_LCDBKLT</SIGNAL>.  Good signal through the cable.
with the LCD disconnected I diode test the LCD side of  <SIGNAL>PPVOUT_SO_LCDBKLT</SIGNAL>  and get 0.5v
Same as with the test screens.    I pretty sure we don't have a screen or cable issue here.   

Any other ideas?   What did I miss?

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-01814</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-A  No back light
threads.message:
You can't get 55V, unless no conection with LEDs strip!
Normal voltage is 45V approx...

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-01814</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-A  No back light
